segments.text: And a lot of the people who I write for have probably never seen that.
I mean, I know you've been asked a dozen times, maybe a hundred times, about the circumstances.
You're contriving a plot to murder the ex-husband.
In fact, he still lives in Santa Barbara.
I always thought he would sue me for saying that, but so far he hasn't.
But generally, if I speak to large groups of people, I check to see if his attorney is sitting in the audience.
I thought about that, actually.
At least he could probably claim some royalties.
Right, right.
I've been dining out on this story for years.
But we went through a very bitter divorce.
This was many years ago.
It was in the early 70s.
And he put me through three custody battles.
And I was... I know I do that when I'm doing research.
You always have to make sure the wheels are turning.
Yes, I'll watch the red light.
I didn't know how to fight.
I thought you could get through life being a nice girl.
So I thought it just will suffice that I'm a good girl.
And apparently that's not the way it works when you're in the middle of a bitter divorce.
So I used to lie awake thinking of ways to do this man in.
And I just thought, I'm sure serious.
I told my wife, Mr. Hewlett.
Oh, absolutely.
And she said, that's wonderful.
I mean, the trick is I've been a law-abiding citizen all my life.
So...

I knew myself well enough to know that if I really tried to act it out, I'd fluff it, you know, because the minute the cops knocked on the door, I'd babble out a confession, and then I'd end up in prison, wearing those terrible prison clothes, eating starched food.
So I thought, well, wouldn't it be wonderful to put this in a book and...
get paid for it.
See, then you have the pleasure of doing somebody in without having to pay the price.
And if you can pick up a couple of bucks in the process, we're way ahead of the game.
And every time you tell this story, you're kind of getting... I know, I know.
I mean, that's the truth.
And Nancy, I was smart enough, though, to realize that I couldn't tell this story from the killer's point of view.
because it'd be a real short series, right?
I don't think you can do 26 books from various pathological points of view.
Well, we'll get to that in a second, but I'm curious about the A, this alphabet device.
Well, yeah, so a lot of things were happening simultaneously that fulminate in this decision to do the alphabet.
I was working in Hollywood at the time, and I'd been there probably eight years, six or eight.
and it was driving me crazy.
I was making good money or what seemed like good money then and I got sick of sitting in meetings at the network with people who were 26 years old telling me how to do my business.
I've been at it too long and most of them had never actually written a word.
They'd all gone to film school so that made them experts on how to write things and I got crankier and crankier and I
They've reached a point where I thought, this isn't right.
If something's making you that angry that often, it's a clue.
She felt like I'm smart enough to figure that out.
So I said, you know, if you don't like the game, don't take the money.
Pardon me, but are they really 26 years old?
Oh, hey, I'm exaggerating.
Some are younger than that.
Oh, yeah.
I mean, sometimes they'll bring in an intern who's a college student,
And you're sitting in this meeting, there's always a guy named Steve with a mustache.
You don't know who he is, but you've got to be polite, because he's going to be the head of the network year after next.
And you're sitting there, and they'll say, well, Steve had a good idea for your script, so you're sitting there, you know, you're taking notes, and Steve gives you the worst idea you ever heard.
Then you find out he's a goddamn intern.
And you have to be polite.
But so I thought to myself, it is time to get back to solo writing, because I started out doing...
mainstream fiction.
I had a couple.
You had a couple.
Yeah.
Who were they with, by the way?
Which host?
One was Macmillan in 1967.
That was Poseidon Day.
And then I had a book published just in England by Peter Owen Limited.
That was called The Wally Madonna War.
These must be very collectible books.
They are.
The Brits discovered that their rights had never reverted, and they were going to do me the incredible favor of reprinting them.
They all kind of fit.
But the Brits are so terrific, because when my agent told the head of Macmillan that I was horrified of the idea, he said, I'm wrong.
Isn't that interesting?
I was fabulous, fabulous.
Surprisingly decent.
Completely decent.
I'm not sure what an American publisher would have done that.
Anyway, I had had my bitter divorce, so I had schemes for doing the man in.
I was about sick of Hollywood, and I knew it was time to salvage whatever talent I had left.
And Hollywood was saying to me, they would say to me in these meetings, well, you know how to do character, but you cannot do plot.
So that pissed me off.
I thought, well, I'm going to teach myself how to do plot, and I'll stick it to you where the sun never shines.
Then I was reading.
My father, you know, had done mystery fiction.
So I had always thought I would try one.
One of my questions for later on, before I forget, is did you learn anything from C.W.?
I'll tell you what I learned from that guy.
So I was reading these Edward Gorey cartoons.
Which are wonderful.
Oh, at the Gashley Crumb Tynies.
I swear one day I'm going to learn that whole set of rhymes.
But it did occur to me that you could do a series of books based
on crime words that pertain to the alphabet.
That's a great, great.
I know librarians love me, booksellers love me.
Yeah, but so Gloria was the... Oh yeah.
I haven't seen that anywhere.
Oh, that was... What was the book once again?
The book is called The Gashley Crumb Tiny, G-A-S-H-L-Y-C-R-U.
I'll find it, I'll find it.
And it goes, A is for Amy who fell down the stairs, B is for
Basil, assaulted by bears.
Excuse for Clara, who died of the plague.
I mean, you know, all these little Victorian children stabbed and burned and falling off bridges.
It was very droll.
So I sat down and sketched out as many words as I could think of in alphabetical order to see if, in fact, there were enough to go around.
And some of those titles were, I have always, you know, it was always A is for alibi, B is for burglary, C is for corpse, D is for dead boot.
A couple of them changed as I actually got to the book.
Did you get 26?
More or less.
There are some letters that are puzzlers, but I don't worry about anything that's not happening right this minute.
Right now we're worried about him.
Right, and it's not going to be for murder, I can promise you that.
I don't know what it'll be for, and I guessed wrong a couple of times, so now I try to be kind of quiet about it, unless I know.
Yeah, if I know what a title is, I'll always tell, but I thought L was for libel, so I spent a long time doing research about product liability and couldn't make the story work.
So you really do get the title, and then the story, and then the... An exception with K. I thought K was for kidnap.
And I worked on a storyline for four months, and I had to finally admit to myself, it's a federal crime.
Kinsey Milhorn would never be called in for any reason whatsoever.
So then I thought, I better call it Chaos for Killer, because that'll cover a multitude of sins.
No matter what I come up with, all I have to have is a murder in that one.
And so that's the one I ended up with.
So you did have the idea when you sold the first book.
This is the first of 26 and possibly... Well, you know how that goes.
You're writing a book, you don't know if you're going to sell it.
You can be full of energy and hope and have great faith in the system, but...
But the concept was there.
Yes, and maybe you sell the first and it never goes anywhere and nobody ever invites you to proceed down the alphabet.
I sold A.S.
for Aladon to Marion Wood on the basis of 65 pages.
There was no, and she didn't do mysteries.
I don't think she knew anything.
I read some quotes from her that she didn't do any of this at all.
But she thought the voice was wonderful.
Well, she thought I knew what I was doing.
Imagine my surprise.
I thought, shit, they're going to pay me money.
Now I've got to finish the book.
But I feel like that to this day.
Every book I do is a surprise to me.
You always feel like you've done it all.
Are you ever anxious going into one?
I mean, there is expectation.
I don't know.
Anxious.
I'm fearful every day.
It can be a form of energy.
It can also really get in your way.
So a lot of my process is just trying to get calmed down to a point where I can do the work.
Sometimes I think my job as a writer is to get out of my own way.
And, you know,
Are you confident that each one is better than the last?
I don't... See, one of the things I've had to learn, and one of the reasons I love what I'm doing is... Okay.
Okay, one of the reasons I love what I'm doing is that I am learning all kinds of things.
One of the things I'm learning is to give up the notion that I can control how other people feel about these books.

other readers will say this is better than the last but that isn't mine to worry about my job is to write each book as well as i can and trust it to do whatever it needs to do so sometimes i get trashed by reviewers i got trashed by the new york times for years for evidence and do you have a thin skin for reviews yeah
I'm beginning to understand that bad reviews are about one person's opinion.
Yeah.
I have to say, this is my first book, and I'm 52, you know.
It's not like I'm a kid.
Yeah, yeah.
But I got one snotty, snotty review, which I mean, I was sore for a week.
I understand that.
Well, I have never forgotten a gal in some part of Texas who said, B is for boring.
To be accused of being boring, would you die?
Well, the guy who published his week, he said, the Bible was big, it's 688 pages, 250,000 words, and the history of it.
And the guy says, he's included everything, including the kitchen sink.
And I feel like saying, well, where is the kitchen sink?
Tell me what page it's on, you know?
Because it's a wise-ass remark.
Everything else has been wonderful.
I have a full page in the Washington Post.
I have a third printing.
I'm only a month old.
You don't have that anyway.
Well, you have to give that up.
I mean, I always react with a wince to that.
It's like being insulted by somebody you never even met.
Like, what did I do to you?
But you must hear wonderful things from your readers.
I do.
And here's the other thing you have to learn.
It's like it's all the same.
The negative and the positive, the good reviews and the bad, none of them help you write the next sentence well.
No, don't.
I am a one-man band.
Forgive me for moving away.
Okay, okay.
Just keep talking.
That's okay.
So I can still talk to you?
Oh, please.
Okay.
That's what's happening right there.
It's just as dangerous in a way to listen to the praise and start thinking of hot shit.
That's worse for you than being a little bit insulted or wounded.
So I try to disregard it all.
And in fact, Marian, I've told her I don't want to read reviews.
You know, it just doesn't help me.
So she doesn't send them to you now?
Nope.
Really?
Yeah.
We talked about the readers.
Do you have a reader and my reader writing these books?
No, I write them until they sound right to me.
So you look basically for yourself?
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
You do a lot of research for all of your books, too.
Could you tell me a little bit about some of the things you've done for Paris?
Oh, how great.
Happily, I've never been arrested.
So in H's for Homicide, when I knew that Kinsey Milhorn was going to get self-arrested so she could make contact with Viviana Diaz, I went over to the jail.
Unfortunately, I live in a wonderful small town where they will help me.
And they walked me through the booking process.
This is Santa Barbara, which is in my book, by the way.
Do you know a fellow by the name of Dave Karpelis?
Yes, I just, honestly, he looks around the corner for me.
It's in my book.
Oh, really?
I went over to their house doing a piece of research.
Really?
For the next book I'm doing.
Okay.
Because I'm thinking it has, there's some little piece of business, which I will not reveal at this point, but David and Marcia are wonderful people.
You should read my chat, my little section on there.
I will.
I'm very curious about them.
Well, I, and I know a lot more about them.
I bet.
Then you put it down.
That's good.
If you're interested, you can call me and say, I'll give you a lot of time.
Okay, okay.
Um,
That's irrelevant to what we're talking about here.
I'm sorry, the police.
My daughter, my younger daughter, said, make sure you tell Sue Grafton we live in Grafton.
Yes, my town.
I give you permission.
Yeah, what else have I done?
I've been through... You went through an autopsy once?
I've never been to an autopsy.
I've been in many morgues.

but I hear autopsy or nasty things, and I understand you can get them on tape now, and I think that might feel, because it's the smell and the sound that I hear is so appalling, and I'm fairly squeamish.
I don't mind dead bodies at all, it doesn't bother me a bit, but hacking and sawing on human flesh.
As a cub reporter, I walked into one by the swamp.
I swear to God, you don't even know the story, but I was drowning, and I was out,
I was looking around, and I walked into this room, and there was a pathologist with this present.
You backed out of that one pretty quick.
I'm pretty tough, but that's what I'm doing.
How about before we forget the influence of your father and mine?
My father died four months before A is for Alibi was published, and he had not read the book because I wanted to present him with the real thing.
But because he wrote himself, he often talked about writing, and I think maybe consciously or unconsciously he was grooming me to do this.
Well, he was doing this.
This was decidedly a male province, though.
Yeah.
But see, the thing about my parents, it never occurred to them to tell me you couldn't do something because you were female.
So that message was never given to me one way or the other.
What my father taught me was to work hard.
They taught me about meritocracy.
And with meritocracy, it doesn't matter if you're male or female, black, white, it just doesn't pertain.
What matters is do you have the ability?
And are you patient?
And are you tough enough to take it?
So he taught me, he used to say, keep it simple.
He would say, it is miracle enough that I can have a thought in my head converted into a

marks on a page that you look at so that the same thought forms in your head so he would always say the writer must never do anything to interfere with that communication so he said spell correctly use proper punctuation yeah and he would teach me for instance he said transitions are important
This is why you were working on A is for Alibi, or even when you were younger?
No, this was just when I started writing when I was 18.
I had nothing to say, but I did it very earnestly.
And the thought was fiction, of course.
Yes.
So he would say to me, every writer has the big scenes.
If you're thinking of a novel, you always imagine the big
confrontations, but he said, if you don't take care of the transitional scenes, you won't have a reader when you get to the vision.
My sense is that you do write very visually, though.
That's what I learned in Hollywood.
But it is kind of paradoxical.
I've read also that no way would you ever sell this character to these people.
That's right.
That's right.
I mean, she must be a rather sacred... They would wreck my work.
You know, I've had too many years
people telling me how to do my work.
I don't tolerate that anymore.
I need, certainly with Marian Wood, I need feedback and I need another untutored eye.
Somebody saying this is confusing, this needs to be expanded on or cut.
You need somebody to give you honest feedback.
I've talked to a number of writers who feel that the space that we do this
perhaps because we love it, but we also do it because we have to live, and that's how we make our living.
And if it became a viable source of income for you, the books are yours.
I mean, don't you accept that they could do something with the character?
I don't.
I don't want to ever give them permission to tamper with my work.
There was an arrogance.
You must have had a tough time.
Oh, I did.
Yeah, and it was a good lesson.
I'll tell you what I learned in Hollywood.
The other thing my father taught me was to pay attention to minor characters.
What I learned in Hollywood, see, I'm a smart girl.
I learn a lot of things from a lot of people.
I learned how to structure a story, and the mystery structure is terribly important, and it's also important in screenplay for one.
I learned how to write dialogue.
I learned how to be economical, how to get into a scene and get out of it.
I learned how to write action sequences.
And all of those are very important to the mystery plot.
When you talk about paying attention to minor characters, that's also the story.
Is this kind of a tip to the reader to be alert?
I think it is a way, it's really about not being a lazy writer.
Not dropping into stereotyping and cartooning the people who pass through your books.
I think John D. MacDonald does a wonderful job of handling minor characters.
So I watch how other writers do things and I learn how I can.
Now, Kinsey is about 33, I guess.
She's 35.
She's 35?
Yeah, she started out 32 when the books first came out in 1982.
Books are sequential, so in her life, three years have passed.
In our lives, 13 have gone by.
When I get to the end of the alphabet, she will turn 40, because she's going to age one year for every two and a half books.
But life begins at 40 for a lot of people.
I know, but she gets to do that in privacy.
Thank you.
Do you suspect that you'll retire her at the age of 40?
I don't know.
She had 14 books.
I'm going to give her the last book.
She gets to do it anything she wants.
It may not even be a mystery.
I don't know what she'll do.
It's a gift.
Yeah, it is.
And it's not mine to determine.
It's a gift from you to kids.
One of the things I've been saying, you know, the woman has taken over my life, and so maybe by the end there will be no Sue Grafton, there will only be Kenzie Milhom.
Because everything I do pertains to her practically.
Is she somebody you'd like to be?
She is a lot of who I am.
The difference is her life is full of genuine adventure.
Mine is full of hard work.
And so the parallels between us are very peculiar because she lives in a very spartan style, a nearly monastic life.
I live very lavishly, thank you, because of her.
So I can say sometimes the smartest thing I ever did was to invent somebody who now supports me.
You know, imagine an imaginary friend who turns out to be your benefactor.
That's it.
I mean, how you can see close and tight.
Yes.
She's an evolving character.
But slowly, I think, as we own.
Which is wonderful because you learn new things about her.
There are textures to her.
She's not pure and perfect in every way.
Oh, God forbid.
I really work to keep her human size.
I don't want her to be larger than life.
I don't want her to be idealized.
And so I like her to be cranky and inconsistent.
And sometimes she has miserable little thoughts, you know.
She can be like we all do.
little petty hatefulness.
I do admire her lying ability, and I do feel I am a quite accomplished liar myself.
Now, this raises something, and whether or not you want to get into it or not, but how do you see this O.J.
Simpson thing affecting your profession?
Because it seems to me that if this guy beats it,
Oh, he will.
And he will.
I'm not asking you for your opinion on it, but anybody did it, obviously.
And if you watch from it, and we've seen it, what does this say?
Oh, here's what's always been true.
There is a huge difference between real homicide and fictional homicide, and this is why people read mystery novels.
In the real world, homicide is, I think the percentage is 65% of all homicides are alcohol-related.
They're generally poorly planned.
They're hasty.
They're impulsive.
And they're pointless.
People kill each other for a pair of tennis shoes.
In fiction, the conceit is that if you are murdered, it is the result of somebody's solid motivation and quite cluttered planning.
If you're murdered in a piece of fiction, somebody's worked at it and has tried to be intelligent and clever about it.
And the other conceit is that if you are murdered in a work of fiction, there is a representative of the law, a detective or a cop who will move heaven and earth to see the justice and stuff.
Pick up the paper and there's no sign of any of that.
In the real world, homicide is pointless, life has little value, and the legal system is pottering and foundering
And we can't look anymore to the courts for a sense of justice and mercy because what we see is killers who are set free six months later.
Have you watched any of this?
Some of it.
I'm really worried I'll get hopelessly addicted.
It's gotten so boring.
Yeah, true.
And the fact that they've allowed this fight.
I've covered a lot of trials as a reporter before I was in.
Yeah.
And I've always said that I would never second this jury because they've seen all the evidence.
That's not the case here.
The whole world has seen more evidence than the children.
Well, they know about it.
Well, that's often true.
There are many things that are not admissible.
Yeah, but it's never on television.
I know.
Gavel-to-gavel coverage.
I know.
It is.
And we've seen the graphic stuff.
Yeah.
But I used to think it would be a hung jury.
Now I think he'll be a critic.
Yeah.
Like it or not, Johnny Cochran has done a fine job of muddying the waters.
Absolutely, histrionics, hysteria, finger-pointing, and all he has to do is create these.
He's done it six different ways, and it's bullshit, but every time you hear about them taking notes, whatever's going down, and it's always about something that would appear to exonerate O.J.
Simpson.
I did an interview with Donald Westlake a couple months back.
Ah, he's a doll.
He's a doll.
And this was, he was so funny, and this was, you know, a lot of things taken off, and I said, well, what do you think?
He said, well, a lot of writing, and he says, I never would have left a glove.
I know.
That made it too easy.
Really?
But who would have thought?
Well, see, if I had done the research, if I had thought of this idea, and had
given it any weight, whatever, and I thought to myself, I'd better go down and talk to the Los Angeles police about whether this would be possible, evidence handled badly.

I know I would have walked in there, they would have assured me that their technicians were impeccably prepared, that the gloves were changed 16 times, that every piece of evidence was long, because that's by the book.
I couldn't believe that.
In a case like this.
I couldn't, they must have known from the outset.
Except that I don't,
Do you think it's relevant to what they... No, no.
I mean, to me, absolutely.
It's rare and... I know, end of story from our perspective.
I call it the Tinkerbell theory, you know, that sort of the pixie fool around and did all this stuff in 20 minutes.
I was just wondering how this effect, it's relevant to this, possibly relevant to this piece, if this trial, this
affects what you... Well, if you had... Because you said, you know, murder is the ultimate evil.
It is, it is.
And if you put this in between the pages of the book, you can have sold two copies.
Especially the tapes.
Oh, spare us the unbelievability of that.
So, I mean, anybody... I know, swear you hadn't said something in ten years, knowing those tapes were sitting out there.
Well... Anyway.
What's your schedule, by the way?
I'm going to go over to Kate's mystery books about five.
Okay, so we'll get some time.
Yeah, we're fine.
I did an interview also with several of these with P.D.
James.
She's a doctor.
She's wonderful.
Of course, I was new to reading these books.
And I said, why does it always have to be there?
I mean, P.I.
P.I.s investigate thousands of them.
Right.
And her answer was, nobody's interested in each day of Granny's Pearls.
Well, I used to say that, because people would ask me, can you have a murder mystery with no murder?
Absolutely not.
Well, a mystery with no murder.
Yeah, but in a way, Lawless is not a murder mystery at all.
It's like a caper.
It's like a zany adventure.
And I think because of Kinsey Millhunt, I can get away with that.
But the stakes have to be high.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
Okay, let me just see now.
How are we doing?
Are we covering your stuff?
Yeah, I'm happy.
Russ McDonald was, it's a nudge.
Santa Teresa was kind of the tip of the hat.
Yeah, exactly.
I got to meet him a couple of times in the 70s, just in passing, and he was always such a quiet man.
Apparently, you know, he died of Alzheimer's, and apparently it took about three years before Margaret Millar figured out if there was anything wrong, because he was always quiet.
But...
Anyway, he was one of those writers.
It was kind of hard to meet him because Lou Archer was so kind of tough and out there, and Ken McGuire was so recessive and shy, and when his books would come out, he would leave town.
He didn't want to be part of any of the fanfare.
So once you met him, you would read Lou Archer, and you would go, what is the connection?
One of the advantages I have with these books is I am Kinsey Milhoun, and people are very clear in making the association between my personality and hers.
So like if people in my signing lines talk about the film rights, they always think I should play her.
I'm not an actress, I'm so old.
Kinsey Milhoun is always going to be younger and braver and thinner than I am.
I know Bob Parker's Spencer kind of grows with him.
It was interesting, which is one way to do it.
Of course, Philip Marlowe never aged, right?
Well, I think a little bit of aging makes a certain amount of sense.
When I started the series, I wasn't sure what I would do with the aging issue, and I just didn't want Kinsey Milholm to end up being ludicrous, you know, 70 years old with an ear horn and a little
pistol in her pocketbook, you know, swinging it.
This has to be measured.
That's right.
I've got to stretch this out.
I always say I'm going to be 108 myself by when we get to the end.
But do you feel the pressure?
I mean, because you have committed yourself to getting one of these guys out.
The pressure is sometimes almost crushing.
So a lot of what I do is
I've talked myself out of that.
And it's connected to the whole issue of reviews.
Again, it's like when you do a piece of work, it is just you and the work.
How it's going to be received, how many copies you're going to sell, whether the critics are going to love it or hate it is not your business.
So you have to stay very pure in your intention.
And the risk is enormous.
for the second book and the third and the fourth.
And it gets... Especially if now the first printing is $750,000.
Yeah.
In fact, I just heard they went back for another $50,000.
I mean...
Some of the things I read when you had 100,000.
I got 34,000 of my book and print.
Listen, that's fabulous.
That's fabulous.
I'm pretty excited.
I think I would be.
My first print was 6,500 copies.
I know, they are.
They're selling from 9 to 1100 books a week.
Yeah, except I don't get the money.
No, of course not.
When you start, do you pretty much have an idea?
No, they told you in Hollywood that you couldn't write until the rap on you was that.
Yeah, there's some critics who still claim I can't just plot.
Is that right?
But that's okay.
That's okay.
Who cares?
But do we start with plot?
Here's what I do.
I do a journal on my word processor.
in which I talk about, it's like a long letter to myself about what I'm doing.
And so I log in, and I generally talk about, sometimes I add a line about, is it raining?
Do I have a migraine?
Is my cat sick?
Because I think that affects your work, you know?
If your spouse is ill, it affects your work.
Then I talk about, that's just one line, I'm not in the business of keeping an endless diary of my growing life.
Then I talk about everything I know about a book, and I play suppose and what if, and I have a lot of big charts because I keep track of whether the killer is male, female.
I keep track of how Kinsey is hired, what she's hired to do and who hires her.
I keep track of what the motive for the crime is so that I don't just do endless repetitions of the same thing.
And I also keep a list of the climaxes of the book so I don't get into unconscious repetition.
I don't want the reader to go, oh boy, here comes the car chase.
Oh man, here's the obligatory, you know.
But it is a genre of books.
